case_name: Khardah Co. Ltd. v. Its Workmen

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated September 19, 1961 of the Fourth Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal in Case No. VIII-42 of 1961.

or violation of a principle of natural justice, or when on the materials, the finding is completely baseless or perverse, vide Indian Iron Steel Company Ltd. v. Their Workmen.  1 . There is no doubt that this Court has consistently refrained from interfering with the conclusions reached. by the enquiry officer who Conducts domestic enquiries against industrial employees unless one of the four tests laid down in the case of the Indian Iron Steel Co. Ltd.  1  is satisfied, because we have generally accepted the view that if the enquiry is fairly held and leads to the conclusion that the charge framed against the employee is proved, the Industrial Tribunal should not sit in appeal over the finding recorded at the said enquiry and should not interfere with the managements right to dismiss a workman who is found guilty of misconduct.

concepts.interpretation: Must be observed in domestic enquiries against industrial employees; includes examining witnesses in presence of workman and recording findings by enquiry officer.

issues.text: Whether the appellant has held a proper domestic enquiry and has dismissed jadav because the management thought that the enquiry disclosed the fact that the charges framed against jadav had been established

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant, the learned Solicitor General has strenuously urged before us that the appellant has held a proper domestic enquiry and has dismissed jadav because the management thought that the enquiry disclosed the fact that the charges framed against jadav had

issues.text: Whether an Industrial Tribunal will interfere with the action of the management in dismissing its employee after holding an enquiry unless shown that the management has not acted in good faith or that the dismissal amounts to victimisation or unfair labour practice, or basic error or violation of natural justice or perverse finding

anchor.surface_text: He contends that it is firmly established by decisions of this Court that an Industrial Tribunal will not interfere with the action of the management in dismissing its employee after holding an enquiry into his alleged misconduct unless it is shown that the management has not acted

issues.text: Whether principles of natural justice must be observed in the domestic enquiry conducted by the management

anchor.surface_text: It would be noticed that the essential basis on which this view is founded is that the enquiry conducted by the management before a domestic tribunal must be a fair and just enquiry and in bringing home to the workman the charge framed against him, principles of natural justice

issues.text: Whether the failure of the Manager to record any findings after holding the enquiry constitutes a serious infirmity in the enquiry itself
Whether the dismissal of jadav was not effected in good faith and has been actuated by a desire to victimise him for his trade union activities
Whether the Tribunal was right in holding that the stand taken by the appellant was wholly untrue and that Mahboob had not been given leave on October 3
Whether it is improper to have allowed additional evidence to be called for after the arguments had been heard

arguments.court_reasoning: Accepts principle but finds infirmities present including natural justice violation and victimisation

arguments.claim: Dismissal of Jadav was mala fide with motive of victimising him for trade union activities

anchor.surface_text: The respondents case was that jadav had been dismissed by the appellant mala fide with the motive of victimising him for his trade union activities. jadav was the Organising Secretary of the Union and since he supported the Unions demands very strongly, the appellant wanted to get rid

arguments.court_reasoning: Conclusion of fact by Tribunal not perverse

arguments.claim: Jadav disobeyed lawful order and incited workers to strike, committing misconduct under Standing Orders Rule 14 (c)(i) and (viii)

anchor.surface_text: misconduct under Rule 14 c   i  and of the Standing Orders. jadav was called upon to offer his explanation within 24 hours after receipt of the charge-sheet. ... The appellants case was that jadav had been working in the weaving department both on plain looms and on looms that produce twill.

arguments.court_reasoning: Stand on Mahboob untrue, changes complexion of charge-sheet

arguments.claim: Mahboob was absent on October 3, 1960, so no question of him working or fainting, strike instigated by Jadav

anchor.surface_text: Regarding the incident of Mahboob, the appellant alleged that Mahboob was absent on October 3, 1960 and, therefore, no question of his working on any machine arose on that day. In other words, the appellants contention was that the Unions version that the strike was spontaneous

arguments.court_reasoning: Minutes of Emergency Works Committee prove Mahboob present and leave refused

arguments.claim: Management suppressed fact that Mahboob attended mill on October 3 and sought leave extension which was refused, so strike not instigated by Jadav

anchor.surface_text: Before the Tribunal, some oral evidence was led by the parties and reliance was placed by the appellant on the proceedings of the enquiry itself. The Tribunal held that the management had deliberately suppressed the fact that Mahboob had gone to the mill on October 3, and prayed

arguments.court_reasoning: Minutes confirm presence and refusal of leave

arguments.claim: No finding recorded by enquiry officer after enquiry, constituting serious infirmity

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal further commented on the fact that after the enquiry was held, no finding was recorded by the Manager who held the enquiry, and it appeared to the Tribunal that the conclusions on which the management presumably acted in dismissing jadav were of such a character

arguments.court_reasoning: Failure to record findings prevents assessing perversity or basic error

arguments.claim: Jadav not accustomed to twill loom, request to work on plain loom justified, charge unjust

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal also held that jadav was not used to work on a twill loom, and so, his request that he should be allowed to work on a plain loom was not unjustified. Its conclusion, therefore, was that a grave charge had been unjustly framed against jadav and that showed

arguments.claim: No need to record findings or formal report as Manager competent to dismiss
arguments.court_reasoning: Object of enquiry is to decide merits; Tribunal needs findings to check perversity

arguments.claim: Principles of natural justice require recording evidence in presence of workman, discourage ex parte statements

holdings.text: This Court has consistently refrained from interfering with the conclusions reached by the enquiry officer who conducts domestic enquiries against industrial employees unless one of the four tests laid down in the case of the Indian Iron Steel Co. Ltd. is satisfied.

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that this Court has consistently refrained from interfering with the conclusions reached. by the enquiry officer who Conducts domestic enquiries against industrial employees unless one of the four tests laid down in the case of the Indian Iron Steel Co. Ltd.  1  is satisfied, because we have generally accepted the view that if the enquiry is fairly held and leads to the conclusion that the charge

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows and applies precedent from Indian Iron & Steel Co. Ltd. outlining four tests for Tribunal interference: lack of good faith, victimisation/unfair practice, basic error/natural justice violation, or perverse finding.

holdings.text: The enquiry conducted by the management before a domestic tribunal must be a fair and just enquiry and in bringing home to the workman the charge framed against him, principles of natural justice must be observed. Normally, evidence on which the charges are sought to be proved must be led at such an enquiry in the presence of the workman himself.

anchor.surface_text: It would be noticed that the essential basis on which this view is founded is that the enquiry conducted by the management before a domestic tribunal must be a fair and just enquiry and in bringing home to the workman the charge framed against him, principles of natural justice

holdings.reasoning_summary: Essential basis for non-interference is fair enquiry observing natural justice; evidence normally in presence of workman.

holdings.text: In such enquiries, it is desirable that all witnesses on whose testimony the management relies in support of its charge against the workman should be examined in his presence... Therefore, we would discourage the idea of recording statements of witnesses exparte and then producing the witnesses before the employee concerned for cross-examination.

anchor.surface_text: principles of natural justice must be observed. Normally, evidence on which the charges are sought to be proved must be led at such an enquiry in the presence of the workman himself. ... Therefore, we would discourage the idea of recording statements of witnesses exparte

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes industrial enquiries from public servant cases; presence ensures caution, no persuasion, better cross-exam.

holdings.text: In our opinion, therefore, the failure of the Manager to record any findings after holding the enquiry constitutes a serious infirmity in the enquiry itself.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Prevents Tribunal from assessing perversity or basic error; object of enquiry is merits decision with recordable conclusions.

holdings.text: It is his duty to record clearly and precisely his conclusions and to indicate briefly his reasons for reaching the said conclusions.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Necessary for Tribunal review of approach/perversity; impairs value of enquiries otherwise.

holdings.text: If the enquiry is held to be unfair, the employer can lead evidence before the Tribunal and justify his action, but in such a case the question as to whether the dismissal of the employee is justified or not would be open before the Tribunal.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Well settled rule when unfairness vitiates enquiry; Tribunal decides merits de novo.

holdings.text: The Tribunal has come to the conclusion that the dismissal of jadav was not effected in good faith and has been actuated by a desire to victimise him for his trade union activities. That is a conclusion of fact which cannot be said to be perverse.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Upholds Tribunal's factual finding as non-perverse; one of grounds for interference.

holdings.text: The Industrial Tribunal was right in holding that the stand taken by the appellant was wholly untrue and that Mahboob had not been given leave on October 3.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Minutes of Emergency Works Committee and Labour Officer statement prove presence and leave refusal; changes charge complexion.

holdings.text: We do not think there is any force in this argument.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Record only to verify Jadav's union position; no serious prejudice.

holdings.text: The Industrial Tribunal was right in not attaching any importance to the enquiry held by the Manager in dealing with the merits of the dispute itself on the evidence adduced before it.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Enquiry vitiated by infirmities (no findings, victimisation); Tribunal correctly went into merits.
